moves.1. c4: With c4 my opponent tells me that he likes slower, more positional games.
moves.1... Nf6: I show that I am going to use an Indian defense.   If he plays d4 straight away then I can play ...e6...Bb4 going into the nimo-indian.  If he plays Nf3 and avoids Nc3 then I can go into my usual Kings Indian set up.
moves.3. b4:
This is Reti's setup against the King's Indian.  He won a famous game against the great Capablanca with this opening.  You can see it at chessgames.com ( http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1102101 )
The idea behind this move is to gain space on the queenside, since black has made no move in the center.  This keeps with the hypermodern approach.
moves.3... Bg7 4. Bb2 O-O 5. e3: This move may not be the best.  I think that it is best to develop the bishop on the h1-a8 diagonal.  on the f1-h6 diagonal the bishop does not do much.
moves.5... c5: I now attack the white "center".  I can't let white develop completely freely or he will take over the whole board.  So I will fight for my space.
moves.6. bxc5: If 6.b5 then the Kings bishop is really in bad shape, and white would lose his play on the queen side.
moves.6... Na6:
To regain the pawn, maybe not the best.  Qa5 was better.  In my research I found that this position had come about once before, with Petrosian playing black ending in a draw.

http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1279145
moves.7. d4 b6: Here I give up material for the initiative and free development.
moves.8. cxb6 Qxb6 9. Qb3: Can't trade queens as I am down material
moves.9... Qc7 10. Be2 Rb8: Tempoing the queen and gaining access to the open b file
moves.11. Qa3 d6 12. O-O Qb6: Continuing to take over the b-file.
moves.13. Bc3 Bf5: With the bishop on c3 guarding the dark squares on the queenside I start to take over the light squares because White's Kings bishop is inactive.
moves.14. Nbd2 Nc7 15. Rab1: A mistake, dropping the exchange.  But things were already becoming difficult for white.  He should have tried to use the extra material and open the center, luckily for me though I had him completely concerned about my side of the board.  (The joys of playing 15xx players!)
moves.15... Bxb1 16. Rxb1 Qc6 17. d5: This move weakens the dark squares on the queen side.  Definitly not good when I am already up the exchange, and penetrating on the queen side.
moves.17... Rxb1+: Trading material, good when up material
moves.23. Nd3 Nfe4 24. Bxg7 Kxg7 25. Qc1 Nxd2: Now I am up two "points".  But sometimes these endgames can be hard to convert if all the pawns are on one side.  So I will play to keep my QS pawn.
moves.51... Rd3: Game over.  Some may ask why did he resign?  Well....  if the bishop moves, say Bc2 then f6#!  I have (with some help) formed a mating net!
